Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Chemically-Enabled Strategies for the Discovery and Characterization of Novel Enzymatic Function
Award.AbstractNarration:
Microorganisms are not only the most abundant form of life on Earth, but they also possess the greatest diversity of metabolic functions. Gaining access to their collective chemical arsenal would significantly enhance our ability to produce essential small molecules ranging from commodity chemicals to life-saving pharmaceuticals. Recent advances in DNA sequencing technologies have delivered a wealth of microbial genomes that provide an unprecedented opportunity for the discovery of new enzymes. The goal of this project is to identify unusual and potentially useful enzymatic chemistry encoded in these genomic data. The discovery of previously uncharacterized enzymatic activity and its introduction into our reaction repertoire will ultimately lead to more efficient and environmentally friendly routes for small molecule synthesis. The specific C-C bond forming enzymes described in this work will be important additions to the synthetic toolkits of both organic chemists and synthetic biologists. These research efforts will also be integrated into a new laboratory-based freshman seminar course that will engage students in the discovery of new enzymes from human gut microbes.


With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Emily Balskus from Harvard University to discover and characterize enzymes that mediate an unusual C-C bond-forming macrocyclizing dimerization step used in the biosynthesis of the cylindrocyclophane family of cyanobacterial natural products. Using a genome mining approach that is guided by chemical knowledge, the PI has uncovered the biosynthetic gene cluster encoding the enzymes responsible for this reaction. The functions and mechanisms of these enzymes will now be elucidated using in vivo and in vitro biochemical characterization methods, an effort that will be enabled by chemical synthesis of crucial substrates. Important mechanistic insights will also be obtained by solving the crystal structures of the enzymes in collaboration with structural biologists. The central educational objective of this proposal is to create a new research-based course for first-year undergraduates focused on using a screening approach to discover novel enzymes from the human gut microbiota. This class will bring the most exciting aspects of scientific training to the forefront of the college curriculum, encouraging interest in further undergraduate research and scientific careers. Overall, the work detailed in this proposal represents an integrated research and education effort at the interface of chemistry and biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to identify unprecedented enzymatic reactions from microbes using chemically guided approaches. Specifically, we aimed to decipher the biosynthetic logic that produces unusual carbon–carbon bonds in small molecules known as cylindrocyclophanes which are produced by cyanobacteria. Additionally, in order to identify new human gut microbiota associated enzymes with unusual reactivity, we used a screening-based discovery approach as the basis for a new research-based seminar course for first-year undergraduates.

To elucidate the biosynthesis of the cylindrocyclophanes, we combined stable isotope feeding studies and in vitro biochemistry. We discovered that biosynthesis of cylindrocyclophane F requires the use of two enzymes with unprecedented mechanisms. The first novel enzyme, called CylC, selectively chlorinates an unfunctionalized fatty acid using what is likely a diiron metal cofactor to activate an inert C–H bond. CylC represents the first diiron enzyme known to catalyze a chlorination reaction. After elaboration of the alkyl chloride substrate by a polyketide synthase, the second novel enzyme, CylK, catalyzes a step-wise dimerization of two late-stage alkyl chloro-substituted resorcinols to form cylindrocyclophane F. This use of an unactivated alkyl chloride substrate for aromatic ring alkylation is unprecedented in enzymology, although CylK appears to be part of a much larger an enzyme family. We further showed that CylK has a broad substrate specificity and can potentially be used as a biocatalyst to synthesize molecules which are difficult to make with traditional chemical methods. These findings provide new insight into the biosynthesis of microbial natural products and provide a starting point to design new biocatalysts for challenging chemical reactions.

The human gut contains thousands of uncultivated microbes with potentially novel enzymology. To explore this untapped source of enzymes, we created a metagenomic DNA library from samples of the human gut microbiota. This allows us to produce enzymes found in the human gut in an organism amenable to laboratory growth such as Escherichia coli. We integrated this research with an undergraduate seminar course designed to provide hands-on research experience for freshmen in STEM fields. The undergraduates in our Freshman Seminar screened the library for genes involved in the metabolism of antibiotics, complex polysaccharides, and azo dyes, designing and optimizing assays of their choice. Over 2 years, we offered the course to 19 students comprising 7 men and 12 women, including 6 underrepresented minority students. A majority of these students had not had any previous research experience. A follow up survey indicated that 80% of respondents are planning on pursuing either an MD, PhD, or dual degrees. On average, respondents reported large gains across all 20 potential benefits we included in the survey (e.g., clarification of career path, skill in interpreting results, skill in science writing, self-confidence, etc.) with the largest reported gains for learning laboratory techniques and improvement in student comfort, confidence, and sense of belonging in science.

Our ability to sequence microbial genomes has far outpaced our knowledge of the chemical reactions at the heart of microbial life. This research program helped to close that knowledge gap by identifying new enzymes and the DNA that encodes them. These new reactions are of general interest to the chemical industry and further development may benefit society by enabling more environmentally friendly routes to important molecules or the synthesis of new biomedical drugs with complex molecular features. The students and researchers funded by this project have received training in research at the interface of chemistry and microbiology, and the project has fostered new collaborations between academic groups at Harvard and other institutions. The project has also supported an undergraduate curriculum that enables discovery-based research in a classroom environment early in students’ college education. The ability to perform original innovative research will help increase undergraduates’ interests in pursuing further training in scientific research. Finally, the project has supported additional mentoring of female students and underrepresented minorities in the fields of chemistry and microbiology. Altogether, the project has been successful in terms of its scientific merit and broader impacts.
